Layout.heading: Agile Game Development with Scrum
Layout.text: Game development is in crisis: facing bloated budgets, impossible schedules, unmanageable complexity, and death march overtime. It’s no wonder so many development studios are struggling to survive. Fortunately, there is a solution. Scrum and Agile methods are already revolutionizing development outside the game industry. Now, the author discusses exactly how to successfully apply these methods to the unique challenges of game development.

Layout.heading: The Problem
Layout.text:
The game industry has several unique challenges:

  • Games take several years to complete
  • Team size is often ~100+
  • Waterfall development model is prevalent in the industry and it doesn’t scale

This has led to a Crisis:

  • Projects go over budget (budgets can be tens of millions of dollars). GTA V cost $265M to make!
  • Projects do not stay on schedule
  • Most games are not profitable
  • Lack of innovation
  • Deteriorating work environment for developers
  • Class action lawsuits against EA

Concluding comments
Layout.text:
The challenge of applying agile isn’t in merely adopting the practices. The practices are simple. The real challenge arises in the collision between the culture of a studio, their publisher, and agile.

Agile methodologies such as Scrum create transparency. Every deficiency that obstructs the best flow of work is singled out for examination. Rather than putting faith in a design document, a game needs to stand on its own merit every iteration.
